body: The assert was removed, because it triggers as soon as the padding bytes in the struct Saved_Friend are non zero. The Tox specification doesn't say anything about the value of these bytes, so we should just ignore them. Found with #1331 --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/1333)

comment_regular_data.body:
It's a bit of a shame to lose this memcmp assert, because it could 
theoretically catch bugs in friend_load() if Saved_Friend changes. But 
I don't see a neat solution which keeps this memcmp assert, and we still 
have a parallel assert when saving, which should catch the same bugs. So 
overall, I think I approve.

Anyone have a dissenting opinion on this?

If we want to keep this assert, we could explicitly zero the padding bytes. I think however, that this assert is bogus from the start, because it relies on the memory layout of the struct, which is not very well defined across architectures.

* Saturday, 2019-08-03 at 02:44 -0700 - sudden6 <notifications@github.com>:

>I think however, that this assert is bogus from the start, because it 
>relies on the memory layout of the struct, which is not very well 
>defined across architectures.

Is specifying LP64 not enough to pin it down?

Obviously it's an ugly assert for an ugly save format. But I don't think 
we should just delete the other one (in friends_list_save()).

Requiring the padding to be zeroed would mean changing the spec and 
adding a check for it in the loading code. Doesn't sound like a good 
idea to me.

> Is specifying LP64 not enough to pin it down?

Not 100% sure if it's the same across different compilers, but didn't research in detail.

> Obviously it's an ugly assert for an ugly save format. But I don't think we should just delete the other one (in friends_list_save()).

The other one (This: https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/blob/master/toxcore/Messenger.c#L3037 ?) makes sense if we can guarantee that:
1) The struct layout is fixed on LP64
2) The padding bytes in the struct are guaranteed to be `0x00`

> Requiring the padding to be zeroed would mean changing the spec and adding a check for it in the loading code. Doesn't sound like a good idea to me.

EDIT: Do you know what this assert should protect from? Maybe it's better to replace it with a test that triggers if the structure is changed.
Yeah, I agree, just brought it up because it's also a possibility to define them as `0x00`.

* Saturday, 2019-08-03 at 04:00 -0700 - sudden6 <notifications@github.com>:

>> Obviously it's an ugly assert for an ugly save format. But I don't 
>> think we should just delete the other one (in friends_list_save()).
>
>The other one (This: https://github.com/TokTok/c-toxcore/blob/master/toxcore/Messenger.c#L3037 ?) makes sense if we can guarantee that:
>1) The struct layout is fixed on LP64
>2) The padding bytes in the struct are guaranteed to be `0x00`

It seems neither is guaranteed by the C spec. I'm basing this on 
6.7.2.1.14 and 6.2.6.1.6 respectively from the draft C11 spec
http://www.open-std.org/jtc1/sc22/WG14/www/docs/n1570.pdf .

So I agree. This assert should die too.

@zugz could you give the lgtm if you agree with the PR? Or are changes needed?

* Thursday, 2019-08-29 at 11:49 -0700 - sudden6 <notifications@github.com>:

>@zugz could you give the lgtm if you agree with the PR? Or are changes needed?

Don't you want to get rid of the assert in friends_list_save() too?

1) is guaranteed by LP64 on every platform we support (linux, *bsd, windows).
2) I don't know why we need to guarantee this.

This assert has caught many bugs before they happened (and maybe 1 or 2 after they happened). If we remove it, we need to put a comment somewhere saying that the save file code for friend saving is frozen and nobody can touch it ever again.

Also, the padding bytes *are* defined by LP64, because before I rewrote this code to be memory-model-independent, it was a simple memcpy into the save file data, so the save file format itself is defined by that memory model and the struct layout. The assert helps us not break that.

> 2. I don't know why we need to guarantee this.

Because when fuzzing they may not be zero and trigger a false positive assertion.

commit.message:
cleanup friend loading

The assert was removed, because it triggers as soon as the padding bytes
in the struct Saved_Friend are non zero. The Tox specification doesn't
say anything about the value of these bytes, so we should just ignore
them.

cleanup friend loading

The assert was removed, because it triggers as soon as the padding bytes
in the struct Saved_Friend are non zero. The Tox specification doesn't
say anything about the value of these bytes, so we should just ignore
them.
